description:
Capsicum annuum, commonly known as the bell pepper or sweet pepper, is a species of annual, herbaceous plant in the Solanaceae family. It is a widely cultivated vegetable crop, native to Central and South America.

The plant typically grows to a height of 0.5 to 1.5 meters, with branching stems and alternate, simple leaves. The leaves are green, ovate, and 6-12 cm in length. The flowers are white, with five petals, and are self-pollinating.

The fruit of the Capsicum annuum plant is a berry, commonly referred to as a pepper or capsicum. The fruits come in a variety of colors, including green, red, yellow, orange, and purple, depending on the cultivar and stage of ripeness. The fruits are usually 5-15 cm in length and 4-8 cm in width, with a crisp, thick flesh and a mild, sweet flavor.

Capsicum annuum is an important source of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, particularly vitamin C, vitamin A, and capsaicin. It is widely used in culinary applications, as well as in traditional and modern medicine for its various health benefits.
